Quote: Better be proficient in one art than a smatter in a hundred.
Author: Japanese proverb

Quote: The absent are never without fault. Nor the present without excuse.
Author: Benjamin Franklin

Quote: Out of sight, out of mind.
Author: Homer

Quote: Deliberate with caution, but act with decision; and yield with graciousness, or oppose with firmness.
Author: Charles Caleb Colton

Quote: The great end of life is not knowledge, but action.
Author: T. H. Huxley

Quote: Actions speak louder than words.
Author: Proverb

Quote: We would often be ashamed of our finest actions if the world understood all the motives which produced them.
Author: Francois de la Rochefoucauld

Quote: Things won are done, joy's soul lies in the doing.
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: A rolling stone can gather no moss.
Author: Pubilius Syrus

Quote: It is attempting to reach the top at a single leap, that so much misery is caused in the world.
Author: William Cobbett

Quote: Ambition and  suspicion always go together.
Author: Georg Christoph Lichtenberg

Quote: Most people would succeed in small things if they were not troubled by great ambitions.
Author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

Quote: Ambition is a vice, but it may be the father of virtue.
Author: Quintilian

Quote: The very substance of the ambitious is merely the shadow of a dream.
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: The virtue of prosperity is temperance; the virtue of adversity is fortitude.
Author: Francis Bacon

Quote: Adversity is the first path to truth.
Author: George Gordon, Lord Byron

Quote: Trial is the true test of mortal men.
Author: Pindar

Quote: Of one ill comes many.
Author: Scottish proverb

Quote: Sweet are the uses of adversity, which like the toad, ugle and venomous, wears yet a precious jewel in his head.
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: Anger begins with folly and ends with repentance.
Author: Henry George Bohn, Pythagoras

Quote: Truly to moderate your mind and speech when you are angry, or else to hold your peace, betokens no ordinary nature.
Author: Cicero

Quote: Beware the fury of a patient man.
Author: John Dryden

Quote: The best answer to anger is silence.
Author: German proverb

Quote: A soft answer turneth away wrath; but the grievous words stir up anger.
Author: Proverbs 15:1

Quote: He best keeps from anger who remembers that God is always looking upon him.
Author: Plato

Quote: There's something wrong, or missing, with any person who hasn't  got a soft spot in their heart for an animal of some kind.
Author: Will James

Quote: In life beauty perishes, but not in art.
Author: Leonardo da Vinci

Quote: A baby is God's opinion that life should go on.
Author: Carl Sandburg

Quote: Life is as tedious as a twice-told tale, vexing the ear of a dr0wsy man.
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: One man in his time plays many parts, his acts being seven ages.
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: The mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation.
Author: Henry David Thoreau

Quote: Only those are fit to live who do not fear to die; and none are fit to die who have shrunk from the joy of life and the duty of life. Both life and death are parts of the same great adventure.
Author: Theodore Roosevelt

Quote: Socialism is a philosophy of failure, the creed of ignorance, and the gospel of envy, its inherent virtue is the equal sharing of misery.
Author: Winston Churchill

Quote: You cannot legislate the poor into prosperity, by legislating the wealth out of prosperity.
Author: Unknown

Quote: What one person receives without working for, another person must work for without receiving.
Author: Unknown

Quote: The government cannot give to anybody anything that the government does not first take from somebody else.
Author: Unknown

Quote: When half of the people get the idea that they do not have to work because the other half is going to take care of them; and when the other half gets the idea that it does no good to work, because somebody else is going to get what they work for, that is the beginning of the end of any nation.
Author: Unknown

Quote: The more I hear people screaming "Freedom, freedom, freedom!," the more I hear their chains rattling.
Author: George Orwell

Quote: I find that the harder I work the more luck I seem to have.
Author: Unknown

Quote: Each problem that I solved became a rule which served afterwards to solve other problems.
Author: Unknown

Quote: Try to learn something about everything and everything about something.
Author: Unknown

Quote: Never give advice in a crowd.
Author: Arabian proverb

Quote: The worst men often give the best advice.
Author: Philip James Bailey

Quote: A fool sometimes gives weighty advice.
Author: Nicholas Boileau

Quote: No one can give you better advice than yourself.
Author: Cicero

Quote: We ask advice, but we mean approbation.
Author: Charles Caleb Colton

Quote: Don't give your advice before you are called upon.
Author: Desiderius Erasmus

Quote: Whatever advice you give, be short.
Author: Horace

Quote: Advice is seldom welcome. Those who need it most, like it least.
Author: Samuel Johnson

Quote: When Thales was asked what was difficult, he said, "To know one's self." And what was easy. "To advise another."
Author: Diogenes Laertius

Quote: Many receive advice, only the wise profit from it.
Author: Publilius Syrus

Quote: The only thing to do with good advice is to pass it on. It is never of any use to oneself.
Author: Oscar Wilde

Quote: Age appears to be the best in four things - old wood best to burn, old wine to drink, old friends to trust, and old authors to read.
Author: Francis Bacon

Quote: Yet somehow our society must make it right and possible for old people not to fear the young or be deserted by them, for the test of a civilization is in the way that it cares for its helpless members.
Author: Pearl S. Buck

Quote: Young men think old men are fools; but old men know young men are fools.
Author: George Chapman

Quote: A man is as old as he's feeling.
Author: Unknown

Quote: Age does not depend upon years, but upon temperament and health. Some men are born old, and some never grow up.
Author: Tryon Edwards

Quote: He who is of a calm and happy nature will hardly feel the pressure of age, but to him who is of an opposite disposition, youth and age are equally a burden.
Author: Plato

Quote: For all gainful professions, nothing is better, nothing more pleasing, nothing more delightful, nothing better becomes a well-bred man than agriculture.
Author: Cicero

Quote: At the third cup, wine drinks the man.
Author: Hokekyou Sho

Quote: America has believed that in differentiation, not in uniformity, lies the path of progress. It acted on this belief; it has advanced human happiness, and it has prospered.
Author: Louis Brandeis

Quote: An appearance of delicacy, and even of fragility, is almost essential to beauty.
Author: Edmund Burke

Quote: Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold.
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: You grow up the day you have the first real laugh - at yourself.
Author: Ethel Berrymore

Quote: As the crackling of thorns under a pot, so is the laughter of a fool.
Author: Ecclesiastes 7:6

Quote: The loud laugh that spoke the vacant mind.
Author: Oliver Goldsmith

Quote: I laugh because I must not cry.
Author: Abraham Lincoln

Quote: Woe unto you that laugh now! For ye shall mourn and weep.
Author: Luke 6:25

Quote: Everything gives cause for either laughter or tears.
Author: Seneca

Quote: The pleasantest laughter is at the expense of our enemies.
Author: Sophocles

Quote: Laughter is not a bad beginning for a friendship, and it is the best ending for one.
Author: Oscar Wilde

Quote: I light my candle from their torches.
Author: Robert Burton

Quote: There go the people. I must follow them, for I am their leader.
Author: Alexandre Ledru-Rollin

Quote: The final test of a leader is that he leaves behind him in other men the conviction and the will to carry on.
Author: Walter Lippmann

Quote: You cannot be a leader and ask other people to follow you, unless you know how to follow too.
Author: Sam Rayburn

Quote: A government of laws and not of men.
Author: John Adams

Quote: Law is a pledge that the citizens of a state will do justice to one another.
Author: Aristotle

Quote: Any law that takes hold of a man's daily life cannot prevail in a community unless the vast majority of the community are actively in favor of it. The laws that are the most operative are the laws which protect life.
Author: Henry Ward Beecher

Quote: He that keepeth the law of the Lord getteth the understanding thereof: and the perfection of the fear of the Lord is wisdom.
Author: Ecclesiastes 21:11

Quote: Law is the embodiment of the moral sentiment of the people.
Author: William Blackstone

Quote: It cannot be helped, it is as it should be, that the law is behind the times.
Author: Oliver Wendell Holmes

Quote: Compassion to an offender who has grossly violated the laws, is, in effect, a cruelty to the peaceable subject who has observed them.
Author: Junius

Quote: Ye shall have one manner of law, as well for the stranger, as for one of your own country.
Author: Leviticus 24:22

Quote: The purpose of law is to prevent the strong from always having their way.
Author: Ovid

Quote: No man is above the law and no man is below it; nor do we ask any man's permission when we require him to obey it.
Author: Theodore Roosevelt

Quote: A fault confessed is more than half amended.
Author: John Harington

Quote: If we had no faults, we should not take so much pleasure in remarking them in others.
Author: Francois de la Rochefoucauld

Quote: No one loves the man whom he fears.
Author: Aristotle

Quote: No passion so effectually robs the mind of all its powers of acting and reasoning as fear.
Author: Edmund Burke

Quote: There is a courageous wisdom; there is also a false, reptile prudence, the result not of caution but of fear.
Author: Edmund Burke

Quote: Fear always springs from ignorance.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Fear is the parent of cruelty.
Author: James Anthony Froude

Quote: Let us never negotiate out of fear. But let us never fear to negotiate.
Author: John F. Kennedy

Quote: Fear is a feeling that is stronger than love.
Author: Pliny the Younger

Quote: Let me assert my firm belief that the only thing we have to fear is fear itself; nameless, unreasoning, unjustified terror which paralyzes needed efforts to convert retreat into advance.
Author: Franklin D. Roosevelt

Quote: His flight was madness; when our actions do not, our fears do make us traitors.
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: To him who is in fear everything rustles.
Author: Sophocles

Quote: Nothing is so much to be feared as fear.
Author: Henry David Thoreau

Quote: Who leads us is less important than what leads us - what convictions, what ocurage, what faith - win or lose.
Author: Adlai E. Stevenson

Quote: Unless we stand for something, we shall fall for anything.
Author: Peter Marshall

Quote: I am as bad as the worst but, thank God, I am as good as the best.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears, and sweat.
Author: Winston Churchill

Quote: The man who does not read good books has no advantage over the man who can't read them.
Author: Mark Twain

Quote: All good books are alike in that they are truer than if they had really happened and after you are finished reading one you will feel that all that happened to you and afterwards it all belongs to you; the good and the bad, the ecstasy, the remorse and the sorrow, the people and the places and how the weather was.
Author: Ernest Hemingway

Quote: Only the suppressed word is dangerous.
Author: Ludwig Borne

Quote: Censorship reflects a society's lack of confidence in itself. It is a hallmark of an authoritarian regime.
Author: Potter Stewart

Quote: Great things spring from casualties.
Author: Disraeli

Quote: Chance favors only those minds which are prepared.
Author: Louis Pasteur

Quote: Chance is a word void of sense; nothing can exist without a cause.
Author: Voltaire

Quote: Change is an easy panacea. It takes character to stay in one place and be happy there.
Author: Elizabeth Clarke Dunn

Quote: There is no sin punished more implacably by nature than the sin of resistance to change.
Author: Anne Morrow Lindbergh

Quote: Everything changes continually. What is history, indeed, but a record of change. And if there had been very few changes in the past, there would have been little of history to write.
Author: Jawaharlal Nehru

Quote: Character is what you are in the dark.
Author: Dwight L. Moody

Quote: You cannot teach a child to take care of himself unless you will let him try to take care of himself. He will make mistakes; and out of these mistakes will come his wisdom.
Author: Henry Ward Beecher

Quote: I have often thought what a meloncholy world this would be without children; and what an inhuman world, without the aged.
Author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

Quote: When children sound silly, you will always find that it is in imitation of their elders.
Author: Ernest Dimnet

Quote: Respect the child. Be not too much his parent. Tresspass not on his solitude.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: To a father waxing old nothing is dearer than a daughter. Sons have spirits of higher pitch, but less inclined to sweet, endearing fondness.
Author: Euripides

Quote: An undutiful daughter will prove an unmanageable wife.
Author: Benjamin Franklin

Quote: It is dangerous to confuse children with angels.
Author: David Patrick Maxwell Fyfe

Quote: Give us the child for 8 years and it will be a Bolshevik forever.
Author: Vladimir Lenin

Quote: Children have more need of models than of critics.
Author: Joseph Joubert

Quote: Even a child is known by his doings.
Author: Proverbs 20:11

Quote: A child tells in the street what its father and mother say at home.
Author: The Talmud

Quote: Children begin by loving their parents. After a time they judge them. Rarely, if ever, do they forgive them.
Author: Oscar Wilde

Quote: It requires more faith to reject Christianity than to embrace it.
Author: Charles Caleb Colton

Quote: This is all the inheritence I can give to my dear family. The religion of Christ can give them one which will make them rich indeed.
Author: Patrick Henry

Quote: The greatest danger to a civilized nation is the man who has no stake in it.
Author: Henry Ford II

Quote: Civilization, in the real sense of the term, consists not in multiplication, but in the deliberate and voluntary reduction of wants.
Author: Mahatma Ghandi

Quote: A civilization which developes only on its material side, and not in corresponding measure on its mental and spiritual side, is like a vessel with a defective steering gear.
Author: Albert Schweitzer

Quote: Our civilization cannot survive materially unless it be redeemed spiritually.
Author: Woodrow Wilson

Quote: A committee is a group of the unwilling, chosen from the unfit, to do the unnecessary.
Author: Unknown

Quote: Common sense is, of all kinds, the most uncommon. It implies good judgment, sound discretion, and true and practical wisdom applied to common life.
Author: Tyron Edwards

Quote: Nothing astonishes men so much as common sense and plain dealing.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: The crown of all faculties is common sense. It is not enough to do the right thing, it must be done at the right time and place. Talent knows what to do; tact knows when and how to do it.
Author: William Mathews

Quote: Common sense is not so common.
Author: Voltaire

Quote: The evil of communism is not its doctrinal content, which at worst is utopian, but its fanatical certainty itself, it's messianic zeal and its brutal intolerance of dissent.
Author: James William Fulbright

Quote: For everything you have missed, you have gained something else; and for every thing you gain, you lose something.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: An appeaser is one who feeds a crocodile hoping it will eat him last.
Author: Winston Churchill

Quote: If you are not very clever, you should be conciliatory.
Author: Disraeli

Quote: Originality can be taken as a mark of instability.
Author: John Kenneth Galbraith

Quote: There's another man within me that is angry with me.
Author: Thomas Browne

Quote: The still small voice. That's conscience.
Author: William Cowper

Quote: There's no witness so terrible, no accuser so powerful, as the conscience that dwells within us.
Author: Sophocles

Quote: The absurd man is one who never changes.
Author: Auguste Barthelemy

Quote: What is conservatism? Is it not adherence to the old and tried, against the new and untried?
Author: Abraham Lincoln

Quote: Without constancy there is neither love, friendship, nor virtue in the world.
Author: Joseph Addison

Quote: What is there in this vile earth that more commendeth a woman than constancy?
Author: John Lyly

Quote: I am constant as the northern start…
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: Contempt is not a thing to be despised.
Author: Edmund Burke

Quote: The usual fortune of complaint is to excite contempt more than pity.
Author: Samuel Johnson

Quote: Man is much more sensitive to the contempt of others than self-contempt.
Author: Friedrich Nietzsche

Quote: None but the contemptible are apprehensive of contempt.
Author: Francois de la Rochefoucauld

Quote: Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
Author: Aesop

Quote: A perverse and fretful disposition makes any state of life unhappy.
Author: Cicero

Quote: True contentment depends not upon what we have, a tub was large enough for Diogenes, but a world was too little for Alexander.
Author: Charles Caleb Colton

Quote: I am always content with what happens; for I know that what God chooses is better than what I choose.
Author: Epictetus

Quote: Who is rich? He that is content. Who is that? Nobody.
Author: Benjamin Franklin

Quote: You traverse the world in search of happiness, which is within the reach of every man; a contented mind confers it all.
Author: Horace

Quote: I have learned, in whatever state I am, therewith to be content.
Author: Hebrews 4: 11

Quote: When we cannot find contentment in ourselves it is useless to seek it elsewhere.
Author: Francois de la Rochefoucauld

Quote: Courage that grows from constitution, often forsakes a man when he has occasion for it; courage which arises from a sense of duty, acts in a uniform manner.
Author: Joseph Addison

Quote: The brave man is not he who feels no fear, for that were stupid and irrational; but he whose noble soul subdues its fear, and bravely dares the danger nature shrinks from.
Author: Joanna Baillie

Quote: Courage is rightly esteemed the first of human qualities because it is the quality which guarantees all others.
Author: Winston Churchill

Quote: Courage may be taught as a child is taught to speak.
Author: Euripides

Quote: It is better to die on your feet than to live on your knees.
Author: La Pasionaria

Quote: I love the man that can smile in trouble, that can gather strength from distress, and grow brave by reflection.
Author: Thomas Paine

Quote: Far better it is to dare mighty things, to win glorious triumphs, even though checkered by failure, than to take rank with those poor spirits who neither enjoy much nor suffer much, because they live in the gray twilight that knows neither victory nor defeat.
Author: Theodore Roosevelt

Quote: Be civil to all; sociable to many; familiar with few.
Author: Benjamin Franklin

Quote: To speak kindly does not hurt the tongue.
Author: French proverb

Quote: Politeness costs nothing and gains everything.
Author: Lady Mary Wortley Montagu

Quote: True politeness consists in being easy one's self, and in making every one about one as easy as one can.
Author: Alexander Pope

Quote: The greater man the greater courtesy.
Author: Tennyson

Quote: Those marriages generally abound most with love and constancy that are preceded by a long courtship.
Author: Joseph Addison

Quote: A man always chases a woman until she catches him.
Author: Unknown

Quote: Bullies are always to be found where there are cowards.
Author: Mahatma Ghandi

Quote: The coward calls himself cautious.
Author: Publilius Syrus

Quote: Cowards die many times before their deaths; the valiant never taste of death but once.
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: Experience is the name everyone gives to his mistakes.
Author: Oscar Wilde

Quote: Extremism in the defense of liberty is no vice. Moderation in the pursuit of justice is no virtue.
Author: Senator Barry Goldwater

Quote: Faith is a higher faculty than reason.
Author: Philip James Bailey

Quote: Faith is like love; it cannot be forced.
Author: Arthur Schopenhauer

Quote: Faith is the antiseptic of the soul.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: He that has his father for judge goes safe to the trial.
Author: Cervantes

Quote: He that honoureth his father shall have a long life.
Author: Ecclesiastes 3:6

Quote: It is a wise father that knows his own child.
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: Fear follows the crime, and is its punishment.
Author: Voltaire

Quote: Be thou faithful unto death.
Author: Revelation 2:10

Quote: Fidelity bought with money is overcome by money.
Author: Seneca

Quote: Let me remind you that credit is the lifeblood of business, the lifeblood of prices and jobs.
Author: Herbert Hoover

Quote: The most skillful flattery is to let a person talk on, and be a listener.
Author: Joseph Addison

Quote: Imitation is the sincerest flattery.
Author: Nathaniel Cotton

Quote: 'Tis hard to find a man of great estate, that can distinguish flatterers from friends.
Author: Horace

Quote: A flattering mouth worketh ruin.
Author: Proverbs 26:28

Quote: But when I tell him he hates flatterers, he says he does, being then most flattered.
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: Flattery is okay if you handle it right. It's like smoking cigarettes. Quite all right, as long as you don't inhale. (Don't internalize it.)
Author: Adlai E. Stevenson

Quote: Lilies that fester smell far worse than weeds.
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: The first degree of folly is to conceit one's self wise; the second to profess it; the third to despise counsel.
Author: Benjamin Franklin

Quote: Folly consists in drawing false conclusions from just principles.
Author: John Locke

Quote: A fool may be known by six things: anger, without cause; speech, without profit; change, without progress; inquiry, without object; putting trust in a stranger, and mistaking foes for friends.
Author: Arabian proverb

Quote: You may fool all the people some of the time; you can even fool some people all the time; but you can't fool all of the  people all the time.
Author: Abraham Lincoln

Quote: The fool doth think he is wise, but the wise man knows himself to be a fool.
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: Let us be thankful for the fools; but for them the rest of us could not succeed.
Author: Mark Twain

Quote: Nothing chills pretense like exposure.
Author: Woodrow Wilson

Quote: The only safe rule is to promise little, and faithfully keep every promise; to speak softly and carry a big stick.
Author: Theodore Roosevelt

Quote: All crime is a kind of disease and should be treated as such.
Author: Mahatma Ghandi

Quote: Criticism is a disinterested eneavour to learn and propogate the best that is known and thought in the world.
Author: Mathew Arnold

Quote: Criticism is dangerous, because it wounds a man's precious pride, hurts his sense of importance, and arouses his resentment.
Author: Dale Carnegie

Quote: They damn what they do not understand.
Author: Quintilian

Quote: They who write ill, … turn critics out of mere revenge  and spite.
Author: John Dryden

Quote: Curiosity killed the cat.
Author: Unknown

Quote: As soon as there is life there is danger.
Author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

Quote: Better face a danger once than be always in fear.
Author: Unknown

Quote: The day has eyes; the night has ears.
Author: Unknown

Quote: The fear of death is worse than death.
Author: Robert Burton

Quote: O death, where is thy sting? O grave, where is thy victory?
Author: 1 Corinthians 15:55

Quote: These have not the hope of death.
Author: Dante

Quote: Dead men tell no tales.
Author: English proverb.

Quote: There were some who said that a man at the point of death was more free than all others, because death breaks every bond, and over the dead the united world has no power.
Author: Fenelon

Quote: Dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return.
Author: Genesis 3:19

Quote: Show me the manner in which a nation or a community cares for its dead. I will measure exactly the sympathies of its people, their respect for the laws of the land, and their loyalty to high ideals.
Author: William E. Gladstone

Quote: Death is a punishment to some, to some a gift, and to many a favor.
Author: Seneca

Quote: Imperious Caesar, dead and turn'd to clay, Might stop a hole to keep the wind away.
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: Getting into debt, is getting into a tanglesome net.
Author: Benjamin Franklin

Quote: And to preserve their independence, we must not let our rulers load us with perpetual debt. We must make our election between economy and liberty, or profusion and servitude.
Author: Thomas Jefferson

Quote: I, however, place economy among the first and most important of republican virtues, and public debt as the greatest of the dangers to be feared.
Author: Thomas Jefferson

Quote: A small debt produces a debtor, a large one, an enemy.
Author: Publilius Syrus

Quote: God is not averse to deceit in a holy cause.
Author: Aeschylus

Quote: Hateful to me as the gates of hell, Is he, who, hiding one thing in his heart, Utters another.
Author: Homer

Quote: You can fool some of the people all of the time, and all of the people some of the time, but you cannot fool all of the people all of the time.
Author: Abraham Lincoln

Quote: There are three persons you should never deceive: your physician, your confessor, and your lawyer.
Author: Horace Walpole

Quote: The wavering mind is but a base possession.
Author: Euripides

Quote: There is no more miserable human being than one in whom nothing is habitual but indecision.
Author: William James

Quote: To be or not to be, that is the question…
Author: Shakespeare

Quote: We have a choice: to plow new ground or let the weeds grow.
Author: Jonathan Westover

Quote: Defeat never comes to any man until he admits it.
Author: Josephus Daniels

Quote: But man is not made for defeat. A man can be destroyed but not defeated.
Author: Ernest Hemingway

Quote: A strong defense is the surest way to peace. Strength makes détente attainable. Weakness invites war, as my generation knows from four very bitter experiences.
Author: Gerald R. Ford

Quote: If we desire to avoid insult, we must be able to repel it; if we desire to secure peace, one of the most powerful instruments of our rising prosperity, it must bee known, that we are at all times ready for war.
Author: George Washington

Quote: To be prepared for war is one of the most effectual means of preserving peace.
Author: George Washington

Quote: Your old men shall dream dreams, your young men shall see visions.
Author: Joel 2:28

Quote: You could cover the whole world with asphalt, but sooner or later green grass would break through.
Author: Ilya Ehrenburg

Quote: All the tyrants of Sicily never invented a worse torment than envy.
Author: Horace

Quote: Where envy and strife is, there is confusion, and every evil work.
Author: James 3:16

Quote: No man likes to be surpassed by those of his own level.
Author: Livy

Quote: A slowness to applaud betrays a cold temper or an envious spirit.
Author: Hannah More

Quote: It is a nobler fate to be envied than to be pitied.
Author: Pindar

Quote: The truest mark of being born with great qualities is being born without envy.
Author: Francois de la Rochefoucauld

Quote: The only stable state is the one in which all men are equal before the law.
Author: Aristotle

Quote: Men are made by nature unequal. It is vain, therefore, to treat them as if they were equal.
Author: James Anthony Froude

Quote: I have no respect for the passion for equality, which seems to me merely idealizing envy.
Author: Oliver Wendell Holmes

Quote: All animals are equal. But some animals are more equal than others.
Author: George Orwell

Quote: Nature knows no equality; its sovereign law is subordination and dependence.
Author: Marquis de Vauvenargues

Quote: I can pardon everybody's mistakes except my own.
Author: Marcus Cato

Quote: The cautious seldom err.
Author: Confucius

Quote: Errors, like straws, up on the surface flow; He who would search for pearls must dive below.
Author: John Dryden

Quote: The man who makes no mistakes does not usually make anything.
Author: Bishop W. C. Magee

Quote: To err is human, to forgive divine.
Author: Alexander Pope

Quote: Fear God, and keep his commandments; for this is the whole duty of man.
Author: Ecclesiastes 12:13

Quote: Education, then, beyond all other devices of human origin, is the great equalizer of the conditions of men - the balance-wheel of the social machinery.
Author: Horace Mann

Quote: I have never let schooling interfere with my education.
Author: Mark Twain
